section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Magnetic Numerals, a set of five Connecting Cubes for each child, and several Connecting Cubes for yourself.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Baby Goes to Market, we saw many people selling things. We are going to pretend we are fruit sellers at the market!

In this activity, each of you will have five Connecting Cubes as “fruit” for your market stall. I will be a farmer who will bring you more fruit to sell. You will need to count all of your fruit and tell me how many pieces of fruit you have to sell in all.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Give each child five Connecting Cubes. Place the Magnetic Numerals in a row from 1–10 in the center of the table. Ask each child to count the fruit they have now, and point to that number.

More Fruit! As the “farmer,” give each child one, two, or three more pieces of “fruit.” Ask, How many pieces of fruit do you have now? Show me! Guide each child to count all of the fruit in front of them, and point to the correct Magnetic Numeral.

Repeat After each child has counted their new “fruit,” give each child one more Connecting Cube. Ask them to say the new total, guiding them to count forward from their previous total instead of recounting all of the Connecting Cubes.

Talk About Counting Forward As children count forward from their original number, many may restart at one. Guide children to see that they can start at the original total and then count on from that number instead of always restarting at one.
Start the activity with only three Connecting Cubes per child. As the “farmer,” only give each child one new piece of “fruit” at a time.
Tell children that you would like each of them to have 10 pieces of fruit to sell in all. Invite children to ask you as the “farmer” to bring them the number of fruit they need to reach 10.
Review key vocabulary words such as market and fruit. At the start of the activity, point to each Magnetic Numeral and have the whole group say the number chorally, counting forward from 1 to 10.
Consider inviting children to draw their own pieces of fruit and cut them out as playing pieces for this activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Magnetic Numerals 1–9.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Baby Goes to Market, we talked about the characters’ feelings. We used the pictures to tell how each character felt.

In this activity, I will hold up a card with a picture of a person who is feeling happy, sad, or tired. You will tell me how that person is feeling. Then, we will sort the cards into piles and count how many cards are in each pile.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Name the Feeling Show one picture card. Ask, How does this person feel? Encourage children to identify the emotion as happy, sad, or tired and explain why the person pictured might feel that way.
Repeat Show the next card and repeat the activity, asking a different child to describe.

Sort and Count Invite children to sort the cards by emotion into three piles: happy, tired, or sad. Then place the Magnetic Numerals in a line in the center of the table. Ask, How many pictures show happy people? Invite children to point to that number. Repeat for the remaining emotions.
Talk About Counting Remind students when counting the cards, the last number said is the number in all. Point to each number and say its name prior to counting.

Model how to look for clues on each card. Think aloud as you describe the person’s eyes and mouth: This person is yawning, and his eyes are closed. I think he might be tired. Ask, What do you notice in the picture?
Invite children to think of other words that might be used to describe the feelings they see in each picture.
Begin the activity by reviewing the words happy, sad, and tired. Encourage children to use hand gestures along with words to tell the story of why each person might feel that emotion.
Encourage children to act out the emotions they see in each card using their whole bodies.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need the Number Cards 1–10.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Baby Goes to Market, we counted the foods that Baby added to Mama’s basket. We also counted the foods Baby took away to eat.

In this activity, we will create a number line. Then, we will tell stories about shopping at a market. We will add food to our basket, and take some away to eat. We will move our fingers along the number line to help us count the foods we add and take away.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Make the Line Encourage children to help you lay out the Number Cards in order on the table.

Add and Subtract Tell a story about adding or taking away food. For example: There is one yam in the basket. I see some ripe bananas! I’m going to add 5 bananas to the basket. Model counting forward 5 more from 1 using the number line, and encourage children to repeat the count after you, moving their fingers from 1 to 6. Now how many pieces of food do we have in our basket?
Repeat Tell more stories about adding food to the basket and taking some away. Have children use the number line to count forward and backward after each word problem, and answer, How many now?

Talk About Number Lines Talk with children about using the number line to count. Be sure students understand that when counting forward the numbers get bigger. When counting back, the numbers get smaller. Ask, How was it helpful to count using the number line?
Create a number line that ranges from 1–6. Count with children, moving your own finger slowly as you count forward and backward.
Challenge children to create their own stories about foods they would like to add and take away from the basket.
Review the number cards and the terms count forward and count backward. Help children answer each word problem by providing cloze sentences and reviewing food vocabulary as necessary.

Consider giving each child a Connecting Cube, and inviting children to move their cubes along the number line as they count instead of pointing. You may also wish to have children draw the number line, and write in the numbers themselves.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need the Number Cards 1–10. You will also need 10 Connecting Cubes for each child, or other counters to serve as “ingredients.”

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Let’s Make Fruit Salad!, we followed directions to mix ingredients together to make a healthy and yummy fruit salad.

In this activity, each of you will have Connecting Cubes that we will use as different “ingredients” to make a fruit salad. I will hold up a Number Card that shows how many of each ingredient we need, and you will count that many cubes and place them in the bowl.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Give each child 10 Connecting Cubes. Tell them that the center of the table is the “bowl” where ingredients need to be added.
Add Ingredients Hold up a Number Card and ask the first child, Can you add this many bananas? Have the child count out that number of Connecting Cubes and add her “bananas” to the “bowl.”

Repeat Continue asking each child to add ingredients to the bowl by holding up a Number Card and asking, Can you add this many [ingredient]? Encourage children to count their “ingredients” aloud one at a time as they add them.

Talk About Counting Mix the Connecting Cubes, and congratulate children on “cooking” their own recipe. Ask, How could we find out how many pieces of fruit we have in our salad altogether? Help students count the total number of pieces, providing support as needed.
Start with Number Cards 1–5, and five Connecting Cubes per child. Count with children as they add their “ingredients” to the bowl.
After each child adds his ingredients to the bowl, say, I changed my mind—that’s too many! Can you take one away? How many fruits are in the bowl now?
Review the Number Cards and key vocabulary, such as fruit salad and ingredients. Provide cloze sentences for children as needed as they discuss the activity: I would add five more gr (grapes).

Have children use tweezers to count their “ingredients” and place them in the bowl. You may also wish to have children draw their own “ingredients” and cut them out as playing pieces for this activity.
